Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research RUI: WormNet II: Assembling the Annelid Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The more than 16,000 recognized species of annelid worms exhibit immense morphological diversity and include such distinct groups as fireworms, earthworms, bloodworms, and leeches. As sediment feeders, scavengers, and predators, annelids occupy terrestrial and aquatic habitats worldwide and are the most abundant fauna (larger than 1 millimeter) in the deep sea, Earth's most extensive habitat. Annelids have economic importance as bait, pests, invasive species (e.g., oyster borers) and ecosystem engineers. Nonetheless, many fundamental questions about annelids remain unresolved because knowledge of their diversity and evolutionary history is lacking. To fill this gap, this international project will assemble the annelid family tree using a large-scale, multi-tiered approach. The oldest relationships will be examined with high-throughput DNA genome sequencing techniques. Recent relationships will be resolved with multi-gene DNA approaches and a community-based sequencing service that will examine approximately 3000 species.

As one of the few segmented phyla, annelids are integral to understanding animal evolution. This project has significant interdisciplinary implications in fields such as developmental biology, paleontology, marine biology, physiology and evolution. Specimens, data, and educational resources will be publicly available. Extensive human resource development includes training more than 25 undergraduates, 5 graduate students and 4 postdoctoral researchers at four institutions, and recruitment of underrepresented groups. K-12 outreach will foster broad scientific participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Annelida is a diverse and ecologically important group of invertebrates that comprises  >16000 described species. Annelid morphological disparity is rivaled only by the diversity of habitats they occupy, including all major marine and aquatic ecosystems, as well as terrestrial environments. They are arguably the dominant faunal group of the deep sea, which covers ~ 60% of Earth’s surface. Moreover, their segmented, yet variable, body plan has been central to numerous hypotheses of animal evolution. This award built on previous NSF-funded work by greatly extending taxonomic sampling of Annelida and increasing the amount of genetic data so that we could resolve the evolutionary history of Annelida at all levels in the tree. We studied the major groups of annelids and how they are related; which extant lineages diverged earliest amongst annelids; and what is the placement of enigmatic groups such as unsegmented Sipuncula. We also developed a community sequencing project so that we could work with annelid biologists across the globe to study the tips of the annelid tree. For example, we examined whether so-called cosmopolitan species in fact represent cryptic species complexes; how invasive annelids are spreading; and where worms on marine mammal bones come from. For this work, I led two international fieldtrips for the WormNet II research team: one to Cape Town and environs, South Africa in 2011 and one to Lizard Island and Sydney Harbor, Australia in 2013; the hundreds of specimens we collected form important voucher collections for future use. I also developed ongoing collaborations with annelid biologists from the US, the UK, and the Galapagos Islands.

In my lab, we generated data for four nuclear-coding genes from over 100 annelids; these data have been analyzed and are being submitted for publication and given the lack of coding gene data available for annelids, the data will provide an excellent resource for other annelid systematists. I have also published several co-authored papers stemming from community sequencing projects.  

Over the course of the award, I trained almost 40 undergraduates in my lab (including 27 women and 6 students of color); the award also supported the career development of a postdoctoral research assistant and a research technician.
